documentType: FBI FD-759 form (Notification of Authority Granted for Use of Electronic Monitoring Equipment) and related consent forms
summary: This document is an FBI FD-759 form requesting and granting authority for consensual electronic monitoring (wiretap, body recorder, CCTV) in the investigation of Alfredo Rodriguez for obstruction of justice. The synopsis details that Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell documents subpoenaed in a civil lawsuit against Epstein to the plaintiffs' attorney, Bradley Edwards, for $50,000. The FBI planned to use an Undercover Employee (UCE) to complete the transaction.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Subject of investigation, former employee of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who contacted attorney Bradley Edwards to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein for $50,000, leading to an FBI obstruction of justice investigation.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing four female plaintiffs suing Jeffrey Epstein. He was contacted by Alfredo Rodriguez attempting to sell subpoenaed documents, reported this to the FBI, and participated in consensual monitoring.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual being sued in a civil case by four female individuals represented by Bradley Edwards. Alfredo Rodriguez was his former employee.

persons.name: James Edwards
persons.role: Attorney (likely a reference to Bradley Edwards)
persons.context: Named in the synopsis as the attorney contacted by Alfredo Rodriguez. This appears to be the same individual referred to elsewhere as Bradley Edwards, the complaining witness.

connections.description: Rodriguez was an employee for Epstein, as stated in the investigation synopsis.
Rodriguez contacted Edwards, the attorney for plaintiffs suing Epstein, in an attempt to sell documents subpoenaed in that case.
Edwards was the attorney representing four female individuals who were suing Jeffrey Epstein in a civil case.

events.title: Rodriguez contacts Edwards about selling documents
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez contacted attorney Bradley Edwards and attempted to sell him documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein civil lawsuit for $50,000, despite having been subpoenaed for them.

events.title: FBI grants monitoring authority
events.description: The FBI Miami field office granted authority to use consensual electronic monitoring (telephone, body recorder, CCTV) in the investigation of Alfredo Rodriguez for obstruction of justice.

events.title: Take down of Rodriguez
events.description: Audio and video surveillance was conducted during the 'take down' (likely arrest) of Alfredo Rodriguez.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell documents subpoenaed in a civil lawsuit against Epstein to the plaintiffs' attorney, Bradley Edwards, for $50,000.
The FBI investigated this as obstruction of justice (18 U.S.C. 1509 & 1510) and authorized consensual electronic monitoring including telephone intercepts, body recorders, and CCTV.
The plan involved the complaining witness (Edwards) and an FBI Undercover Employee (UCE) making recorded calls and meetings with Rodriguez to complete the document transaction.
Rodriguez was ultimately taken down (arrested) on November 3, 2009, with the operation captured on audio and video surveillance.
